title: Takeo Takahashi (footballer)
text:
(former name; Takeo Kimura, 木村 武夫) is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Takahashi was born in <a href="Shinagawa">Shinagawa</a>, <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> on May 13, 1947. After graduating from high school, he joined <a href="JEF%20United%20Chiba">Furukawa Electric</a> in 1966. In <a href="1967%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">1967 season</a>, he scored 15 goals and became a top scorer. He was 20 years old, this is the youngest top scorer in <a href="Japan%20Soccer%20League">Japan Soccer League</a>. He left the club in 1973 and entered <a href="Tokyo%20University%20of%20Agriculture">Tokyo University of Agriculture</a>. After graduating from Tokyo University of Agriculture, he joined Division 2 club <a href="Hokkaido%20Consadole%20Sapporo">Toshiba</a> in 1979. In 1979, the club won the champions in Division 2. He retired in 1982.
National team career.
In December 1966, Takahashi was selected <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> for <a href="Football%20at%20the%201966%20Asian%20Games">1966 Asian Games</a>. At this competition, on December 17, he debuted against <a href="Thailand%20national%20football%20team">Thailand</a>. He also played at <a href="Football%20at%20the%201970%20Asian%20Games">1970 Asian Games</a>. This competition was his last game for Japan. He played 14 games and scored 4 goals for Japan until 1970.
Coaching career.
After retirement, Takahashi became a manager for <a href="Hokkaido%20Consadole%20Sapporo">Toshiba</a> (later "Consadole Sapporo") in 1987. In 1989, he led the club to won the champions in Division 2 and promoted to Division 1. He managed the club until 1996.
